SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCE: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A. METHOD OF COMPLETING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible to answer. If there is not sufficient space for answers, blank spaces may be used. It is best to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914. It may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: Was Did Western Canadian Pioneers Know?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

My chief impression in the early years was the quiet, hardworking life, after living in the Islands where people were civilized types.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Many moved early due to work opportunities in the city. In 1892-93, there was a large demand for labor in the city, so many moved there.

35. Did many people move during the 1920s? If so, what was the reason?

Yes, many people moved during the 1920s. The main reason was the demand for labor in the city.

I have an old note on the Yukon field year.

It's about 1½ miles north and three miles east. After the country office was closed in 1928, the name was taken from the station on the Yukon Branch of the C.N.R. On the branch started at about a turn up the river, named Stanley by a man named Mr. Fleming in the district, but later renamed impacts of Yukon. The post office was discontinued about 1917 and the name taken from the station on the C.N.R. It called this district hill in 1903 was lost by winter. An early treaty, but was charged to Stanley about 1908 when the post office was discontinued and its name taken away. The entire name was changed for a third time, and became Glenora. Probably affected by mining boom. In many years a winter.

An old school district was formed here in 1914 and named Barrow by the missionary family after their native village - Barrow, Scotland. This also became the name of the village on the C.N.R. close to the school.

Ralph J. Leach

S. Ottewell, Clerk
I have an old photo of the Yukon field year.

The county office was closed in 1928. The name was taken from a station on the Whitehorse Branch of the C.N.R. On the branch started about a year ago, the county was named "Yukon" by order of the district, but it remained unpopulated at first. The name "Whitehorse Station" was given by the C.N.R. It served as an early trading post, but was closed to farming about 1908 when the post office was discontinued and its name changed. The village name was changed from "Third Town" to become "Glenora." Probably suggested by "Yukon Miners." In many years a trading post district was formed here in 1914 and named "Barron" by the miners' family after their native village - Barron, Scotland. This also became the name of the village near the C.N.R. close to the school.

Ralph J. Smith

S. Ottenbacher, Lusk.
